---
title: "Quarto Features Demo"
author: "Ersin Yilmaz"
date: "2025-11-02"
categories: ["demo", "quarto"]
description: "Examples of useful Quarto features for blogging"
draft: true
---

## Callout Blocks

::: {.callout-note}
This is a note callout - great for additional context.
:::

::: {.callout-tip}
## Pro Tip
Use callouts to highlight important information!
:::

::: {.callout-warning}
Be careful with this approach in production.
:::

::: {.callout-important}
Critical information goes here.
:::

## Code with Execution

::: {.cell execution_count=1}
``` {.python .cell-code code-fold="false"}
# Python code that actually runs
data = [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]
avg = sum(data) / len(data)
print(f"Average: {avg}")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
Average: 3.0
```
:::
:::


## Code with Syntax Highlighting (no execution)

```javascript
// Just syntax highlighting
function greet(name) {
  console.log(`Hello, ${name}!`);
}
```

## Math Equations

Inline math: $E = mc^2$

Display math:
$$
\frac{-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac}}{2a}
$$

## Mermaid Diagrams


```{mermaid}
graph LR
  A[Start] --> B{Decision}
  B -->|Yes| C[Do Something]
  B -->|No| D[Do Something Else]
  C --> E[End]
  D --> E
```


## Tabbed Content

::: {.panel-tabset}

### Code
```python
def fibonacci(n):
    if n <= 1:
        return n
    return fibonacci(n-1) + fibonacci(n-2)
```

### Explanation
The Fibonacci sequence where each number is the sum of the two preceding ones.

### Output
```
0, 1, 1, 2, 3, 5, 8, 13, 21...
```

:::

## Two Column Layout

:::: {.columns}

::: {.column width="50%"}
**Left column**

- Point one
- Point two
- Point three
:::

::: {.column width="50%"}
**Right column**

- Another point
- More details
- Final thought
:::

::::

## Figure with Caption

![This is a figure caption](https://via.placeholder.com/600x300){#fig-example}

See @fig-example above for an example.

## Collapsible Code

::: {.cell execution_count=2}
``` {.python .cell-code code-fold="true" code-summary="Show complex code"}
# This code is hidden by default
import random
numbers = [random.randint(1, 100) for _ in range(10)]
print(f"Generated: {numbers}")
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
Generated: [88, 5, 58, 37, 33, 65, 89, 57, 90, 62]
```
:::
:::


## Useful Tips

- Set `draft: true` in frontmatter to hide posts
- Use `#| echo: false` to hide code but show output
- Use `#| eval: false` to show code but not run it
- Add line numbers with `#| code-line-numbers: true`
